column1: #Text=The heat requirement of the system includes 733 BTU/gallon to heat the solution from the absorber bottom temperature of 172.degree.

#Text=F.; 419 BTU/gallon for the heat of reaction required to vaporize H.sub.2 S from a rich loading of 0.7 mols/mol amine down to a lean loading of 0.046 mols/mol amine; and 85 BTU/gallon representing the latent heat content of the saturation steam leaving the top of the regenerator column at a temperature 2.degree.
#Text=F. higher than that of the incoming rich solution.
#Text=The total heat requirement of 1237 BTU/gallon of solution amounts to 2023 BTU/pound of H.sub.2 S removed.
#Text=The lean loading of 0.046 mols/mol amine has been determined by calculation using a regeneration model based on classical theory and verified by commercial plant experience.

#Text=To illustrate the acceptability of a lean loading of 0.046 mols H.sub.2 S/mol amine, the Table shows that the equilibrium concentration of H.sub.2 S in the gas above this solution in an absorber column operating at 1000 psig would be 3.9 volume parts per million at 120.degree.
#Text=F. and 2.0 volume parts per million at 100.degree.
#Text=These represent the lowest levels to which H.sub.2 S could be scrubbed with this lean solution in an absorber operating at 1000 psig.

#Text=Example 2 shows the heat requirement for regenerating the same rich monoethanolamine solution as in Example 1, with the exception that the spent/lean heat exchanger on the full flow of spent rich solution is used, as in known conventional operations.
#Text=The heat exchanger is sized to give a temperature approach at the cold end between the lean and the rich solutions of 48.degree.
#Text=F., which is in line with conventional practice.
